page.title: 09TRANSPORT
page.content: Before the area was drained in the seventeenth century movement in and around the area was very difficult. The landscape was marshy and difficult to move through, the main methods of transportation were either by flat bottomed boat or by horseback along known shallower regions. The area was isolated (part of the reason why the monastry was established at nearby Ely 1 mile away). A raised causeway was built from Stuntney to Ely and the main A142 follows the route of it today. The railway passes through the area as does the main A10(T) road. The general communications network is adequate but there are areas not well served by roads. One result of the shrinking of the land is that the river, roads and railways are all to be found higher than the land, a typical fen feature.
